Description: Rim sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; lotus-palmette and palmette chain in added white outline with added red centres; top of rim glazed; exterior: band of diagonal strokes between lines; below, painted decoration consisting of male figure to right (part of head with red fillet in hair, shoulder and part of beard remaining).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University College London. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The exterior and interior surfaces of the sherd were burnt during the bombings in London in 1941 during WWII. For parallels regarding the interior and exterior decoration, see British Museum 1888,0601.501 which Lemos ascribes to the Naukratis Painter. The painter and the group are named after a chalice found at Naukratis and the slip on all vessels from this group is a light beige to almost creamy white. Rim patterns are very simple and there is no filling ornament. The depiction of figures, however, is very elaborate. Clothing is rendered highly decorated and naked skin is expertly portrayed.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0832) (phase 2)
